page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 307: Line 307:
===11 February===
===11 February===
  +
[[File:Celebratory protesters.jpg|thumb|Egyptians in Giza celebrate Mubarak's resignation.]]
[[File:Protesters with soldier.jpg|thumb|left|upright|A soldier joins the protesters in celebration of Mubarak's downfall.]]
[[File:Protesters with soldier.jpg|thumb|left|upright|A soldier joins the protesters in celebration of Mubarak's downfall.]]
Shock that Mubarak did not step down on Thursday 10 February resulted in a nationwide escalation of protests on 11 February, named again as the '''"Friday of Departure"''' by the opposition movement.<ref name="signonsandiego1">{{cite news | last = Schemm | first = Paul | last2 = Michael | first2 = Maggie | agency = Associated Press | date = 2011-02-05 | url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/11/mubarak-leaves-cairo-for-sinai-as-protests-spread/ | title = Mubarak leaves Cairo for Sinai as protests spread | publisher = SignOnSanDiego.com | accessdate = 2011-02-12 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Egypt's army vows smooth transition|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121217639448807.html|accessdate=February 13, 2011}}</ref> Massive protests continued in Cairo, Alexandria, and other cities. The presidential palace and parliament still remained surrounded by protestors and thousands of people surrounded the state TV building, keeping anyone from entering or leaving. The army issued a ''[[communiquÃ©]]'' in support of Mubarak's attempt to remain ''[[de jure]]'' president while delegating his powers to Vice President Suleiman.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egyptian army backs Hosni Mubarak and calls for protesters to go home|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/11/egyptian-army-backs-hosni-mubarak|first=Paul|last=Owen|date=2011/02/11|publisher=Guardian.co.uk}}</ref> Hossam Badrawi, the new secretary of the NDP, resigned from his position from the party due to his unhappiness with Hosni Mubarak's refusal to step down.<ref>[http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/latest-updates-on-day-18-of-egypt-protests/?hp "Latest Updates on Day 18 of Egypt Protests"] by Robert Mackey - ''The New York Times.'.' Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref>
Shock that Mubarak did not step down on Thursday 10 February resulted in a nationwide escalation of protests on 11 February, named again as the '''"Friday of Departure"''' by the opposition movement.<ref name="signonsandiego1">{{cite news | last = Schemm | first = Paul | last2 = Michael | first2 = Maggie | agency = Associated Press | date = 2011-02-05 | url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/11/mubarak-leaves-cairo-for-sinai-as-protests-spread/ | title = Mubarak leaves Cairo for Sinai as protests spread | publisher = SignOnSanDiego.com | accessdate = 2011-02-12 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Egypt's army vows smooth transition|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121217639448807.html|accessdate=February 13, 2011}}</ref> Massive protests continued in Cairo, Alexandria, and other cities. The presidential palace and parliament still remained surrounded by protestors and thousands of people surrounded the state TV building, keeping anyone from entering or leaving. The army issued a ''[[communiquÃ©]]'' in support of Mubarak's attempt to remain ''[[de jure]]'' president while delegating his powers to Vice President Suleiman.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egyptian army backs Hosni Mubarak and calls for protesters to go home|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/11/egyptian-army-backs-hosni-mubarak|first=Paul|last=Owen|date=2011/02/11|publisher=Guardian.co.uk}}</ref> Hossam Badrawi, the new secretary of the NDP, resigned from his position from the party due to his unhappiness with Hosni Mubarak's refusal to step down.<ref>[http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/latest-updates-on-day-18-of-egypt-protests/?hp "Latest Updates on Day 18 of Egypt Protests"] by Robert Mackey - ''The New York Times.'.' Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref>
Line 313: Line 314:
==== Resignation of Mubarak ====
==== Resignation of Mubarak ====
â
[[File:Finally a free country.jpg|thumb|upright|A protester holding a placard saying "''Finally: a free country.''"]]
+
[[File:Mubarak resignation announcment.jpg|thumb|[[Omar Suleiman]] announced that Mubarak is resigning from Presidency]]
Vice President Omar Suleiman announced from the Presidential Palace after 18:00 Cairo local time (GMT +2) on 11 February that the presidency had been vacated and the army council would run the country:<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" />
Vice President Omar Suleiman announced from the Presidential Palace after 18:00 Cairo local time (GMT +2) on 11 February that the presidency had been vacated and the army council would run the country:<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" />
Line 321: Line 322:
====Celebration====
====Celebration====
â
[[File:Celebratory protesters.jpg|thumb|left|Egyptians in Giza celebrate Mubarak's resignation.]]
 
Mubarak's resignation was followed by nationwide celebrations.<ref name="ahram1"/>
Mubarak's resignation was followed by nationwide celebrations.<ref name="ahram1"/>
